Thanks to the support of Manuela Ramos, her business is growing, her clients are satisfied with her products, and her income is growing more and more every day. Along with their children, they’re going to make the business prosper and grow for the wellbeing of the whole family.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer

. La señora Marita pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Fresitas”, vive en Jr. Los Cedros Mz. 265 Lt. 3, del distrito de Yarina Cocha del departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 42 años y es madre de 3 hijos, de los cuales dos ya son mayores de edad y uno aun depende de ella. Está casada, su esposo es empleado, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos de la casa, es así que Marita, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) decide poner una panadería y comprar un motocar de segunda, para poder tener mas ingresos económicos en su familia. En la actualidad cuenta con una pequeña panadería que instaló en su propia casa y útiliza el motocar para distribuir sus panes. Ella y su esposo se levantan a las 4.00 de la mañana para amasar el pan y que estén listos a las 6 para poder repartirlos y venderlos a sus clientes, después hace el desayuno de sus hijos para que puedan ir a sus respectivos centros de trabajo y estudios. Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 3,000 (US$ 1003.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará 1 saco de harina, 1 caja de manteca, 3 paquetes de levadura, 2 bolsas de mejorador, ½ saco de azúcar, 2 paquetes de gaseosas grandes y dos cajas de gaseosas chicas, y también comprará piezas para su motocar. Marita está muy feliz porque siente que todos sus anhelos se están realizando gracias al apoyo de Manuela Ramos, su negocio crece, sus clientes están satisfechos con sus productos y las ganancias aumentan cada día más y más. Junto a sus hijos van a hacer que el negocio prospere y crezca mas para su propio bienestar familiar.

loans.use: To buy ingredients.  To buy soda.  To buy motorcar parts.

loans.name: Sandra Carolina

texts.en:
Sandra Carolina, or ‘Sandy’ as her friends and family tenderly call her, is twenty-one years old and she lives with her partner. Sandy is the owner and operator of a beauty salon that she started three years ago. She offers various services: hair straightening, hair dyeing, hairdos and so on. She also sells beauty products and fashionable hair accessories.

As she talks about her dreams for the future, Sandra Carolina explains that she hopes her salon can be very successful and that she can increase her income. That way, she will be able to attend university next year.

Sandy will invest her loan in the purchase of wigs, hair dyes, and other goods to use to run her business. She will also buy a new mirror since her old one has been broken and couldn’t be repaired.

loans.use: To purchase products for hair and a new mirror to continue operating  her beauty salon

loans.name: Dmytryi

texts.en:
Dmytryi B. lives in Nikopol and runs a business selling hats and caps at the central city market. His vending facility has a very favorable location. Dmytryi has been in this trade for 4 years. Throughout these years his business has remained stable, and been strengthened by Dmytryi’s integrity and thorough approach to every detail. Currently, he has about $4,000 worth of goods in inventory. His monthly net profit is about $500.

Dmytryi is requesting a loan of $1,200 to increase his inventory and earnings. One of his long-term plans is to expand his business and purchase a small vending facility that would work as a store to sell hats. Dmytryi has previously benefited from the lending services provided by “Nadiya Ukraine” and has established a reputation for honesty as he has worked with our organization. We believe this loan will provide further assistance to Dmytryi as he seeks to develop his business and increase his income.

loans.use: Increase inventory for his clothing stall

loans.name: Rubenia Del Socorro

texts.es:
Rubenia’s business is located in her own home. It is a general store that she has run with great energy for the past ten years. The store is located in the city of Chinandega in the Somotillo zone.

Rubenia has three school-aged children and she is very proud that they are excellent students. She feels committed to continuing to improve her business in order to support her children.

In order to reach this goal she has contacted Ceprodel to request a loan that will allow her to purchase more product. She feels satisfied that her previous loans have allowed her to improve her economic condition and have helped her meet her children’s needs. Currently she needs to purchase more product for her store in order to obtain better earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

El negocio de la señora Rubenia lo tiene ubicado en su casa de habitación siendo este una pulpería que desde hace 10 años ha venido supliendo con mucho esfuerzo en su localidad de habitación en la ciudad de Chinandega específicamente en el municipio de Somotillo.

Es madre de tres hijos en edad escolar de los cuales se siente muy orgullosa por ser buenísimos estudiantes y por esta razón se siente comprometida con continuar mejorando su negocio para apoyar a sus hijos.

Para lograr esta meta ha acudido a Ceprodel para ser apoyada con créditos que le permitan la compra de los productos. Es por esta razón que se siente muy satisfecha porque desde que ha recibido crédito ha mejorado su condición económica y le ha brindado todos lo que necesitan a sus hijos. Actualmente su necesidad es la compra de los productos para obtener mejores ingresos.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Rosalina Arnaldo

texts.en:
Rosalina, or as she kindly introduced herself “Rosa”, is 47-years-old and originally from Bela Vista, in the Maputo Province. She has been married for 2 years with her third husband. The first marriage lasted 5 years and Rosa had a girl, who unfortunately died one day after she was born. Rosa never had any children again.

After the Mozambican civil war was over, Rosa decided to come back to Maputo Province, where she felt she belonged. In 1995, Rosa moved to Ponta D’Ouro to look for work opportunity. Ponta D’Ouro is a beach village bordering South Africa famous for its tourism. For the past 11 years, Rosa has worked as a cook at the local diving camp from 5:00am to 4:00pm.

Rosa’s monthly salary of 1,000 Rand (approximately US$140) was only raised twice in 11 years. She decided to ask for a loan to build her own cement house. This will be Rosa’s third loan with Hluvuku, the first 2 were used to buy construction material and begin construction. This loan of MTn 10,000 will be used to buy aluminum roofing. Rosa believes that with 2 more loans she will be able to finish her house and conclude a lifetime dream.

loans.use: Buy construction material

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.es:
Marcelina lives on Pasco Street in the Rio Seco zone of the city of El Alto. She is divorced and lives with her 16-year-old son. She sells rice, noodles, cooking oil, and other goods for a living, allowing her to receive daily income.

The loan being requested will be used to repair the front part of her house and to build a small general store, where she will sell her products with more comfort.

This is the client’s first loan with Impro. Her credit evaluation qualifies her to receive the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Marcelina vive en la Calle Pasco D. la zona D. Rio Seco ubicada en la ciudad D. El Alto. Ella es divorciada y vive junto a su hijo D. 16 años. Se dedica a la comercialización D. arroz, fideo, aceite y otros al por menor, por lo cual recibe ingresos diariamente.

El crédito requerido será destinado para la refacción D. la parte frontal D. su casa y la construcción D. una pequeña tienda D. abarrotes en donD. expenderá con mayor comodidad sus productos.

Es el primer crédito que Impro le otorga a esta clienta, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: Remodelling and construction

loans.name: Mataifono

texts.en: Mataifono T., 45, is married with children.  She has many year(s) of experience in the Male and Female outfit business. She sells to the villagers/public 5 days per week. She has 1 previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Mataifono’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be able to utilise to improve her business

loans.use: fabrics, cotton threads, sewing machine, etc

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr:
Awa Samaté, 38, is married and raising 6 children. She has been a member of the village bank Boucotte Sud Grand Dakar for three and a half years. She wants to start back up and bolster her businesses making and selling ready-to-wear (for children and adults) and selling groceries. She has two canteens and a stall in the open-air market of Grand Dakar. She has put sewing machines and a refrigerator in one of the canteens. In the other and in the stall she sells grocery items such as palm oil, honey, vegetables, etc. Awa wants to improve the living conditions and health of her family. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid at the end of six months in one single payment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Awa Samaté, 38 ans mariée, 06 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Boucotte Sud Grand Dakar depuis 3 ans et demi. Elle veut reprendre et renforcer ses activités de confection et vente de prêt à porter (pour enfants et adultes) et de produits alimentaires. Elle a deux cantines et un étal au marché de Grand Dakar. Elle a mis des machines à coudre et un réfrigérateur dans l’une des cantines et dans l’autre et l’étal sont vendus les produits alimentaires comme l’huile de palme, le miel, les légumes et autres. Awa cherche à améliorer les conditions de vie et de santé de sa famille. Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use:
Purchase fabric for sewing clothing and groceries for re-sale

Acheter des tissus pour la confection des habits et des produits alimentaires et vendre

loans.name: Irene

texts.es:
Irene, 30 years old, is the mother of two children who are going to school and are her motivation to get ahead. She lives with her husband José Carlos who helps her in everything and agrees with the goals she has set. She has a small business selling lubricants and parts for motorcycles and motorcars. She is in charge of administering the business and her husband works providing mechanic services out of their home. Irene brings him the clients. She has worked in this activity for the past two years and she likes it very much because she meets many people. Through her business she supports her family and her children’s education. Irene wants to expand and start her business and later also wants to help her husband to start his with some tools and work better; this is why she is turning to all of you in search of your support through a loan of a thousand soles.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva volunteer.

Irene tiene 30 años, es madre de dos hijos, los cuales están estudiando y son sus ganas de seguir adelante, ella vive junto a su esposo José Carlos, quien la apoya en todo y está de acuerdo con sus metas trazadas. Tiene su pequeño negocio de venta de lubricantes y repuestos para motos y motocarros, es la encargada de administrar y atender en su negocio, su esposo trabaja brindando los servicios de mecánica en su propio domicilio y es quien le trae los clientes a Irene. Ella se dedica a esta actividad desde hace 2 años y le gusta mucho su porque conoce a mucha gente. Mediante su negocio ve el sustento diario de su familia, y la educación de sus hijos. Irene quiere ampliar e implementar su negocio, y desde luego apoyar también a su esposo para implementarse con algunas herramientas y trabaje mejor; por ello recurre a ustedes en busca de su apoyo mediante un préstamo de mil soles.

loans.use: To purchase the products that she sells (lubricants and motorcycle parts); additionally, she wants to acquire some tools that her husband needs to work.

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.es:
La Señora Candelaria es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Valerosas II”, vive en la región y  provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto. Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en general, ya tiene buen tiempo en este negocio y le va bien. El negocio está ubicado en su propia casa en el Jr. Tulumayo  S/N, en la Asociación de Vivienda San Genaro, lugar donde acuden diariamente sus clientes, los cuales son mayormente los vecinos de su  barrio.

Con el préstamo de S/. 2,500, el cual pagará en 6  meses, comprará  productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar en saco, leche, aceite, conservas en cajas de diferentes tamaños, papel higiénico en paquetes, detergentes, jabones de diferentes marcas y tamaños, frutas y verduras, entre otros,  para surtir bien el negocio y sus clientes logren encontrar lo que buscan. 

La señora Candelaria tiene 35 años, vive con su esposo y sus 03 últimos hijos, quienes la apoyan en la atención de los clientes en sus momentos libres. Es una mujer trabajadora, carismática y con muchas ganas de seguir trabajando con el negocio porque le gusta lo que hace, su meta es continuar con el negocio, seguir creciendo y tenerlo bien surtido para la satisfacción de ella y de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mrs. Candelaria is a member of the “Courageous Women II” communal bank and lives in the San Martín region and province, in the district of Tarapoto. She has worked selling groceries for some time, and the business is going well. The business is located in her own home on Tulumayo S/N Street, in the San Genaro Housing Association, a place where her customers come daily. The majority of the customers are people from her neighborhood. With this loan of 2,500 soles ($850), which she will repay over 6 months, she will buy essential products such as rice, sacks of sugar, milk, oil, preserves in boxes of different sizes, packages of toilet paper, detergents, soaps in different brands and sizes, and fruits and vegetables, among other things, in order to supply the business well so her customers can find what they are looking for. Mrs. Candelaria is 35 years old and lives with her husband and 3 youngest children, who help her to attend to the customers in their spare time. She is a very hard-working woman and charismatic, and has a great desire to keep working in the business because she likes the work. Her goal is to continue with the business, keep growing, and to have the business well-stocked for her own satisfaction and that of her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy essential products such as rice, sacks of sugar, milk, oil, etc.

loans.name: Dulce Maria's Group

texts.en:
Dulce Maria is married with two daughters, one of whom attends school.  Her husband is doing military service at Cotuí, in the province of Sanchez Ramirez in the central part of the country.  To supplement her family's income, Dulce sells an assortment of cosmetics to women in her neighborhood.  She has been selling these goods for more than five years, and currently she has a well-established clientele.  The entrepreneur has requested a loan to add new and exclusive products to her inventory.  That way, she'll be able to increase her earnings and improve her family's life.

These are the women who'll receive the loan together with Dulce Maria:
Rafaela S. S., who'll invest in beauty products for her small business;
Teofila Gonzalez Sanchez, to purchase women's clothing to retail;
Claudina Morel Otanez, who operates a small fruit and vegetable stand; and
Maritza Reyes Hilario, who owns a small grocery store.

Pictured from left to right are Rafaela, Dulce Maria, Teofila, Claudina and Maritza.

loans.use: To invest in new cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Cathérine

texts.fr: Âgée de 27 ans, dame D. Cathérine est originaire de Porto-Novo, la capitale politique du Bénin. Mariée à HOUNKONNOU Hounhoui, mécanicien automobile, elle est mère de 02 enfants. Initiée à la vente de boule de pâte de maïs bouillie (akassa) par sa mère et dans la vente de trousseaux pour bébé par sa tutrice, elle a choisit se lancer dans la vente de fruits pour son propre compte avec l'aide de son mari. Elle est une semi grossiste. Elle livre les fruits en gros ou au détail à ses différents clients. Parfois elle se transforme en ambulante pour pouvoir vite écouler sa marchandise. Elle sollicite ce sixième prêt de 120000fcfa pour une durée de 08 mois en vue de devenir grossiste. Elle compte s'approvisionner en ananas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Cathérine D., 27, comes from Porto-Novo, the political capital of Benin. Married to Hounhoui Hounkonnou, a car mechanic, she is the mother of 2 children. Her mother taught her to make and sell maize (corn) porridge balls (akassa) and her guardian taught her to sell baby layettes, but she chose to sell fruit on her own with the help of her husband. She is presently a semi-wholesaler. She delivers fruit wholesale or retail to her various customers. At times, she does door-to-door sales so as to sell her merchandise quickly. She is requesting this, her sixth loan of 120,000 F CFA for a period of 8 months in the hopes of becoming a wholesaler. She intends to buy pineapples.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 40 sacks of pineapples

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase confections, cookies, and softdrinks wholesale.

loans.name: Salomat

texts.en:
Salomat is a devoted mother that struggles day after day to provide the best for her family. Ten years ago, she got the idea to start raising cattle to contribute to the family finances, taking advantage of the space she had available in their land for this business. She is engaged in this business together with her husband. Slowly, the number of cows increased and her clients started asking for more and more. With an endless list of requests, she has finally decided to increase the number of livestock she keeps and for this reason she is requesting a loan. Be an important part of the growth of Salomat’s business.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is one of the poorer of the 15 former Soviet Republics, with a GDP per capita of less than $600. The civil war, which took place soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., severely damaged the already-weak economic infrastructure and caused a sharp decline in agricultural production and the manufacturing sector.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  All of these factors have resulted in a severe lack of jobs and have forced hundreds of thousands to leave Tajikistan to find work in other countries, mostly in Russia.  While Tajikistan has experienced some economic growth since the end of the Civil War, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty. 

IMON International's mission is to promote sustainable economic development and improved quality of life in Tajikistan by insuring reliable access to financial services for the economically active members of the population. IMON has eight branch offices throughout Tajikistan and their entrepreneurs work in many parts of the country's economic sector including trade, manufacturing, agriculture, and services. As of October 2008, IMON had 27,802 active clients and a total portfolio of $28,405,549.  Approximately 44% of these clients are women and 65% are from rural areas.  To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing adult and young cattle to expand the business.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La señora Juana M. V. es casada, su esposo se dedica a hacer trabajos de albañilería, ellos tienen dos hijos.
La señora Juana M. está solicitando un préstamo para comprar materiales con los cuales piensa remodelar los interiores de su casa, su esposo se encargará de la mano de obra debido a que él se desempeña en este tipo de trabajos. Esta remodelación ayudará a que ella y su familia vivan en un hogar mejor.
texts.en:
Juana Martinez Velazquez is married with two children; her husband is a construction worker. She is requesting a loan to purchase materials to remodel the interior of her home. Her husband will take care of the labor since he has plenty of experience in this type of work. This remodeling will help her and her family to live in a better home.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Interior remodeling

loans.name: Jama Khan

texts.en:
Jama khan lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan and is married with three children. He owns a general store and is requesting a small loan for his brother’s business because it is a new business. Jama requested an individual loan of 50000 afghani for the term of 12 months and he wants to make his business larger and expand it. Also, he wants to complete his stocks of his business and buy necessary materials for his shop.

 Jama khan is really happy with this process of loans in Afghanistan. He wants to thank all lenders of Kiva and AFSG in Afghanistan.

loans.use: he buy necessary materials for his shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Build a fence around a hallway

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en: Cynthia I. is a trader.Her husband is a taxi driver and she has three dependents.She sells goods like plastic and aluminium bowls at Ankaful near Elmina, which she has been doing since 2008. She has received a junior high school education. She intends on using the money to buy more products to sell.She would then use the profit she gains to pay her utility bills and also buy land to build a house for her family.

loans.use: She intends on using the money to buy more products to sell.

loans.name: Bake Tinkouwe

texts.fr: Bake Tinkouwe a pour activité  la vente d’objets en plastique et de produits de beauté.  Elle a commencé ce commerce en 2005.  Voulant agrandir son stock pour mieux vendre et pour mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, elle sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter 20 seaux, 20 bassines, 50 gobelets, 1 carton de plats, 40 glacières et 1 carton de pommades.elle habite à Agoe, un quartier au nord de Lomé, la capitale du Togo.  Elle et mariée, et elle a un enfant.
texts.en:
Bake Tinkouwe's business consists in selling plasticware and cosmetics. She started this business in 2005. Eager to bolster her stock in order to increase her sales, and to better meet customer demand, she's seeking her first loan. She intends to use it to buy 20 buckets, 20 basins, 50 cups, 1 box of trays, 40 coolers, and 1 box of ointments. Bake Tinkouwe lives in Agoe, a neighborhood in the north of Lomé, the capital of Togo. She's married and has one child.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell plasticware and cosmetics

loans.name: Ayda

texts.es:
AYDA M. C. pertenece al Banco Comunal “LAS MARGARITAS” vive en Av. Colonización c/16 de noviembre. del distrito de Callería, en la ciudad de Pucallpa, tiene 32 años de edad y 1 hijo.  Su pareja es motocarrista (servicio de transporte).

Se inició en el negocio de manualidades y costura hace algunos años,  Su primer préstamo fue de S/.300.00 Nuevos Soles, con este dinero compró telas e hilos, cuenta con clientes frecuentes y su negocio ha ido creciendo.

Actualmente se dedica a la costura, su clientela ha aumentado.   Con este crédito de S/. 1,000.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará una máquina de coser.

“Me encanta lo que hago.  Gracias a Manuela Ramos que me dio esta gran oportunidad para generar ingresos con lo que me gusta hacer y además  me permite cubrir las necesidades de mi casa.
texts.en:
Ayda M. C. is a member of “Las Margaritas” Community Bank and lives on Colonización Avenue in the Callería district of the city of Pucallpa. She is 32 years old and has one son. Her husband drives a motorized rickshaw.

A few years ago, Ayda began a handicrafts and sewing business. Her first loan was for 300 Peruvian nuevos soles, which she used to purchase fabric and thread. She has many regular customers and her business has grown.

She currently focuses on sewing, and her clientele has expanded. She will use this loan for 1,000 nuevos soles to purchase a sewing machine.

Ayda says, “I love what I do. I am grateful to Manuela Ramos for giving me the opportunity to increase my income doing what I love while meeting my household expenses.”

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase one sewing machine.

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en: Ngozi resides in Lagos state, Nigeria. She is married with three children. She is 49 years old. She sells fruits like watermelon. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more fruits to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits to sell

loans.name: M H 2 Group

texts.en:
Anastasia D. L. R. is the group coordinator for this group of entrepreneurs. She has had a rough time since she first became a client of Esperanza International about eighteen months ago (this is her third loan cycle). She's had to change her business activity several times, going from a fried food stand to selling undergarments. Unfortunately, her undergarments sales did not go as expected; so for this new loan she has decided to try a new business. She will take orders for small appliances, purchase them with the loan money, and then collect payments from her customers. The one thing that has not varied is her clientele. They have continued to purchase from her in every business activity she has tried.

Anastasia is very concerned about having a successful business because she has seven children. She not only has to proviD. for them every day, but she hopes to be there for them until they can go to college and start their own careers.

Please help us support Anastasia and the rest of these entrepreneurs with this Kiva loan. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase small appliances to sell.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie C., 47 years old, started her business 20 years ago. She always wanted to assist her husband in farming to earn enough to be able to send their seven children to school and to meet their daily needs. She plans to acquire another hectare to expand the business. But in the meantime, her main concern is to sustain her business. In order to this, she’ll need additional capital to purchase fertilizer and other farming necessities.

Thus, she applies for a Php 10,000.00 loan from the Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). Since CEVI offers wide services aside from the loans they, Rosemarie is confident that she can meet her obligation responsibly and their ambition to have a better life is now just a few steps away.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other necessities

loans.name: Llerme

texts.es: La señora Llerme, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Los Próceres”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 40 años y es madre de 06  hijos, 04 que aun dependen de ella.Llerme es una mujer alegre, perseverante y capaz. nos cuenta que poco a poco ha ido logrando algunos de metas y sueños que quería realizar,  en la actualidad se dedica a venta de ropas y le esta yendo muy bien ya que tiene clientes que la conocen y saben de su negocio que se  encuentra ubicado en el Mercado Nº 02 de la cuidad de Tarapoto.La fortaleza y la perseverancia que le caracteriza, le ayudo a crecer como mujer independientemente y esta muy orgullosa con lo logrado.Con este préstamo de S/. 2,200.00, comprará  más productos para surtir su mercadería de ropas como: pantalones, shorts, snikers, blusas en todas las tallas y modelos, polos y vestidos para niñas. Ella manifiesta que siente mucho orgullo por ella misma, por lo que logrò y lo hizo con mucho entusiasmo y optimismo.Dice: Agradezco la oportunidad que me da  Manuela Ramos  de  contar con los  préstamos que me ayudan a desarrollarme como mujer y pequeña empresaria.
texts.en:
Llerme belongs to the “Los Próceres” (National Heroes) Community Bank in the district of Tarapoto, province of San Martín, Peru. She is a 40-year-old married mother of six children, four who are still dependent upon her. Llerme is a happy, perseverant and capable woman. She tells us that little by little she has been fulfilling some goals and dreams she wanted to realize. Currently she makes a living selling clothing and it is going very well since she has customers who know her and know her business, which is located in the a local market in Tarapoto. Her strength and perseverance have helped her grow as an independent woman, and she is very proud of what she has achieved. With the loan of 2,200 soles she is requesting, she plans to purchase more products to stock her clothes inventory, such as pants, shorts, sneakers, blouses of every style and fabric, polos, and children's clothing. She says she feels very proud of herself and what she has accomplished with a lot of enthusiasm and optimism. She says, "I am grateful for the opportunity that (Kiva partner) Manuela Ramos gave me by providing the loans that helped my small business grow and myself grow as a woman."

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothes to supply her store

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine R. is engaged in a fruit-juice-processing business in the rural area of Santos Quezon, Isabela. She makes and processes vinegar and fruit juice and she also manages a hog-raising business in her backyard. She sells her processed products in stores in her village.  

Justine wanted to increase her capital, so she is asking for financial support from Kiva of PHP 11,000. The continuous support of Kiva lenders and the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) will allow her to improve her business and expand her customer base. She also hopes that her business will provide jobs for the unemployed some day.

Justine is married to Renie R. who has a thriving tricycle-based transport business. They are blessed with two children who are in high school. In the meantime, their children serve as their helpers to deliver their products to stores on weekends. Justine is happy that her family helps to fulfill their dreams in life.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Roberto Carlos

texts.es:
Roberto Carlos O. G. es socio del Banco Comunal Las Estrellitas, un grupo de 11 socias (casi todas mujeres) que se dedican al comercio. Ellas viven por diferentes lugares de la ciudad de Cuenca como son muy buenas amigas todas decidieron formar responsablemente el Banco Comunal, se llevan muy bien entre todas y se respaldan mutuamente, porque desean el bienestar de todas ellas y la superación de cada una.

Roberto vive en el sector la Gloria, en las calles Ave. Loja y Pichincha, en la ciudad de Cuenca, tiene 37 años de edad, está felizmente casado y tiene una buena relación con su cónyuge, fruto de su amor procreo  5 hijos de 13, 11, 6, 3, 1 año de edad, su primera hija y el segundo  estan en el colegio Garaicoa, el tercero a la escuela 3 de Noviembre, no viven en casa propia. 

Trabaja como vendedor ambulante de mercadería de acuerdo a la temporada (toda la ropa que se encuentre a la moda), su horario es de 8 a.m. a 5 p.m. de lunes a sábado, le encanta su trabajo y no ha tenido ninguna dificultad en el.

Nos cuenta que lo bueno de ser negociante es ser dueño de su propio tiempo por lo que comparte con los seres que más ama, se lleva muy bien con todos los socios de mi bankito, es su segundo ciclo trabajando junto a la FUNADACION ESPOIR y se siente muy contento y agradecido por las facilidades que le conceden.

El préstamo que realiza lo invertirá en la compra de mercadería surtida, porque  realizará viajes a Quito, Latacunga, Guayaquil y otras ciudades del país para traer más y mejor mercadería y, de esta manera abastecer con suficiente stock su negocio para los último meses del año.

Su sueño para el futuro es darles todos los estudios a sus hijos para que lleguen a ser  profesionales  y tratar de reunir un dinero para su vejez.
texts.en:
Roberto Carlos O. G. is a member of the Communal Bank “Las Estrellitas”, a group composed of 11 members (mostly women) who engage in their own businesses. They live in different areas within the city of Cuenca. The members are all very good friends who decided to get together to form a responsible Communal Bank. They get along well and are supportive of one another because they are concerned about the well-being of the group and helping each other overcome obstacles.

Roberto lives in the area of La Gloria, which is near the streets of Ave. Loja and Pichincha in the city of Cuenca. He is 37 years old, happily married, and has a good relationship with his wife. They produced 5 children (ages 13, 11, 6, 3, and 1). The oldest two children attend Garaicoa School, while the third child attends the “November 3” School. They do not own their home.

Roberto is a door-to-door salesman who offers seasonal merchandise (all clothing that is in fashion). His work schedule is from 8am to 5pm, Monday through Saturday. He enjoys his job and does not experience any difficulties with it.

He tells us that the best thing about being a businessman is managing his schedule so that he can spend time with the people he loves the most. He gets along well with the other members of Mi Bankito, who are starting their second loan cycle with Fundación ESPOIR. They are very happy and grateful for the services provided to them.

Roberto will use his loan to purchase merchandise on his trips to Quito, Latacunga, Guayaquil, other cities around the country. He will bring back more merchandise of better quality, which should give him sufficient inventory to last his business until the end of the year.

He dreams of providing for his children’s future education so that they can become professionals and of saving enough money for retirement.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase enough merchandise to last until the end of the year

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 54 years old and married with 7 children. She sells sarongs and has been in business for a long time. She lives in Ibadan. She hopes for the amount of N50,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Inyh

texts.en: Inyh C. is a 21-year-old woman from Agusan del Sur. She tills a hectare of rice field, which, she says, needs additional financial support to ensure a rich harvest. Upon learning about CEVI in April 2009, she immediately joined without hesitation. Now she is requesting to borrow Php 8,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase farm inputs. This loan will help Inyh in her goal to preserve her farm and produce a quality harvest.

loans.use: Farm inputs

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
“Achieving success in life is not that easy,” says Carmen C. of Barangay Villa Magat San Mateo, Isabela. Carmen is 41 years old, she is a single parent to her two children who are Rheden - 18 years old, and King Klay - four years old. Her eldest is a graduate of two year course in college while her youngest is in kindergarten.

Carmen manages a general store. Her daily income from the business is used to support the studies of her children to give them a bright future. She wants to improve her business and be able to increase her income. However, she does not have enough capital to use, thus she wants to ask for a loan from Kiva lenders of 5,000 Philippine pesos. This amount will be of great help in maintaining her business and increasing her store's inventory. Some of the things that she will buy are canned goods, basic commodities and toiletries. She is doing everything to develop her business and to sustain her family needs.

loans.use: To expand store inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy and sell food items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock

loans.name: Lucia Mercedes

texts.es: Lucia tiene 19 años, vive en casa de su madre con sus hermanos. Lucia  hace 1 años se inicio en el negocio de la venta de golosinas, juguetes y prendas de vestir por catalogo, inicio con capital propio algunos ahorros, su padre se encuentra trabajando en Chile y le envía remesas a su madre para el sustento del hogar. Lucia le ofrece la mercadería que compra en la ciudad de Lima a menor precio, a las personas que venden en los colegios de su localidad y las prendas de vestir a sus amigas del instituto y amistades de su mama. Actualmente cuenta con mas pedidos, la mayoría de sus clientes son de la misma zona donde ella vive, solicita el crédito para la compra de la mercadería que ofrecerá en la temporada navideña. Lucia tiene el sueño de acabar su profesión de Técnica en Farmacia y poder ayudar a su madre, contar con mayores ingresos el cual le ayudara a incrementar su negocio.
texts.en:
Lucia is 19 years old and lives at home with her mother and siblings. One year ago, she used her savings as capital to start a business selling candy, toys, and clothing by catalog. Her father works in Chile and sends remittances to her mother in order to maintain the household. Lucia buys her merchandise in Lima at a low price and sells them to people at the local high schools. She sells clothing to her friends at the institute and to acquaintances of her mother.

Lucia currently receives many orders. The majority of her customers live in the same neighborhood as her family. She is requesting a loan to purchase merchandise to offer for the Christmas season. Lucia dreams of becoming a pharmacy technician so that she can help her mother. By generating more income, she will be able to increase her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for the Christmas season

loans.name: Josephine

texts.fr: A. Josephine est née en 1954 à Agbangnizoun au Bénin. Josephine vit depuis 10 ans à Cocotomey, non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est une veuve et mère de 5 enfants, tous scolarisés. Josephine vit seule avec ses enfants, et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Josephine n'a pas été à l'école. Il y a 5 ans environs que Josephine vend des condiments de sauce (piment, moutarde locale, tomate fraîche, oignons, gingembre, etc.) et également de l'huile de palme et des poissons frits à son domicile et au marché Pahou, dans la commune de Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Josephine s'approvisionne. Josephine a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, crédit qui a été bien remboursé. En vue d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et d'agrandir son activité, Josephine sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Josephine A. was born in 1954 in Agbangnizoun, Bénin. For 10 years she has lived in Cocotomey, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. She is a widowed mother of 5 children, all of whom are in school. Josephine lives alone with her children and is the sole family breadwinner. She did not go to school. About 5 years ago, Josephine began selling sauce condiments (chili pepper, local mustard, fresh tomato, onion, ginger, etc.), palm oil, and fried fish from her home and at the Pahou market in the Ouidah community, a historic village in Bénin. Josephine buys her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. She received a first loan from ALIDé which she repaid in full. Wanting to increase her income and grow her business, Josephine is asking for a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 1 Basket of Peppers, 2 Baskets of Fresh Tomatoes and one Sack of Onions

loans.name: Talumps Group

texts.en:
This group of business people are residents of Magburaka town, in northern Sierra Leone. They named their group 'Talumps' and made Fatmata K., on the right in the photo, their leader. They have been in business for many years but their businesses have not been doing fine. They thus formed themselves into a group of four and applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 each from SMT/Kiva Lenders.

Fatmata was born in Magburaka town. She is thirty years old, married with three children. Fatmata’s husband is a businessman and her children are attending primary and secondary schools respectively.

Fatmata has been a businesswoman for ten years now. She sells ready-to-wear-clothes, shoes (sandals), towels, and napkins. Fatmata will use this loan to add stock to her business – she will buy clothes for children, shoes, and towels.

loans.use: To add stock to her business: clothes for children, shoes, and towels

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr:
Madame Fatou T. est une femme âge de 45 ans, mariée,  mère de 6 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 13 et 26ans. Elle habite dans le quartier de Ngaparou dans le village de Yoff. Elle est sociétaire de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC de Yoff depuis janvier 2009 et a déjà bénéficié d’un prêt antérieur. Elle évolue dans le commerce plus precisement dans la vente de biscuits qu’elle achète a l’usine depuis plus de 15 ans. C’est par passion de cette activité qu’elle a délaissé l’aviculture pour s’orienter vers la vente de biscuits. Son objectif est d’être  indépendante financièrement  afin qu’elle puisse satisfaire ses propres besoins. Pour Madame T. ce qui l’intéresse le plus dans son occupation c’est son caractère lucratif. Elle sollicite un crédit de 250 000 frs pour l’achat de sac de biscuits diversifies .Son souhait est d’accroitre son chiffre d’affaire et en même temps ses bénéfices. Elle participe dans la gestion  familiale en couvrant une partie des dépensés quotidiennes.
Toujours  dans son optique de participer activement a la lutte contre la pauvreté   l’U-IMCEC avec l’appui positif des prêteurs   réussit   à soutenir  les populations  à exercer des  activités  lucratives génératrices de revenus, ce  qui favorise un développement  socio économique   apprécié.
texts.en:
Mrs Fatou T., aged 45, is married and the mother of six children aged between 13 and 26. She lives in the neighborhood of Ngaparou in the town of Yoff. She has been a member of the Yoff branch of the microfinance institution U-IMCEC since January 2009 and was granted already one previous loan. She has been a seller of cookies for over 15 years. She buys her supply at the factory. She abandoned her previous poultry farming activity, because she had a passion for selling. Her goal is to be financially independent, so that she can provide herself for her own needs. This is why the lucrative aspect of her business matters a great deal to her.

Mrs T. applies for a loan of 250,000 CFA francs to buy bags of miscellaneous cookies. She wants to increase both her turnover and her earnings. She participates in the family charges and contributes to the daily household expenses.

Always looking to actively participate in the fight against poverty, U-IMCEC – with the positive support of lenders – succeeds in supporting people in revenue-generating activities which promote valuable socioeconomic development.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Nuestra socia  MARGARITA, pertenecen al banco comunal “PRO DESARROLLO”, la socia vive en Pisac situado en la provincia de Calca departamento de Cusco, está a 40 minutos de la ciudad, es un pequeño pueblo heredero de unas bellas construcciones incas, aquí lugar obligado de paso para todo aquel turista que visita la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia tiene 42 años de edad, ella es conviviente  y tiene 5 hijos, nuestra socia además de alternar sus actividades del hogar, tiene un stand de artesanía en el cual vende todo tipo de artesanía, especialmente bisutería, nuestra socia realiza aretes, collares, pulseras, anillos, gargantillas, y mucho más para lo cuál requiere el préstamo para comprar materiales como alambre, pedrería, mostacillas, pines y todo lo que se requiere para armar la bisutería, Nuestra socia también tiene un carrito de pollipapas, ella a partir de las 6:00 p.m. saca su carrito y vende (pollos dorados con papas), Nuestra socia es muy trabajadora y a dado mucho ejemplo a sus hijos los cuales también tiene sus propios negocios.

La socia agradece y valora la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio, así mismo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our member, MARGARITA, belongs to the "PRO DESARROLLO" community bank. She lives in Pisac, 40 minutes from the Peruvian city of Cusco. Pisac is a small town, a heritage site with lovely Inca-era buildings that is an obligatory stop for tourists on the way to Cusco.

Margarita is 42 years old, partnered, with 5 children. She spends part of her day taking care of her family and the other part managing her crafts business. She sells all kinds of crafts, but her specialty is jewelry. She makes earrings, necklaces, bracelets, rings, among other things. She is applying for a loan because she has to buy the materials she needs for the business: wire, semi-precious stones, beads, pins and other supplies for making jewelry. Our member also owns a food stand where she works from 6:00 p.m. selling "pollipapas" (fried chicken with french fries). She is a very hard worker and a good example to her children who have their own businesses.

Margarita is grateful for the opportunity that micro-lending offers her and she is committed to repaying the loan on time.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials for crafts business.

loans.name: Lê's Group

texts.en:
T. Lê Đắc (20209010016) is a 34-year-old male living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  T. is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Thôn Đông - Nhóm 03 (Nhóm 03).


T. is married and has a school-aged child.  To making a living, T. owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising chickens for sale.  T. has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2008, T. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  T. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,704,000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.  He is now requesting a new loan of 6,496,000 VND, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.  The loan will be the third loan taken out by T. from SEDA.  T. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Nguyễn Thị Toán (20209010015) is a 35-year-old female who is requesting a 6,496,000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


T. Lê Đắc  (20209010016) là 34 tuổi nam.  Anh ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  T. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 2 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Thôn Đông - Nhóm 03 (Nhóm 03).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gà để bán.  T. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, T. kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2008, T. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  điều kiện và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  T. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.704.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua thức ăn gia súc & các loại cung cấp khác.  Anh ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.496.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nguyễn Thị Toán (20209010015) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.496.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva

loans.use: To purchase  feed & other supplies

loans.name: Diana Florencia

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mas que Vencedoras está ubicado en la ciudad de Azogues capital de la provincia del  Cañar, a 50 km de la ciudad  se encuentran las ruinas de Ingapirca uno de los sitios turisticos  más visitados del Ecuador, Azogues y Cañar son famosos por su artesanía, especialmente por la elaboración a mano  de los sombreros de paja toquilla y sus productos cerámicos, su gente es cordial y muy amable como nuestras socias que cada día buscan la manera de salir adelante con sus familias.

Diana es socia del banco comunal Más Que Vencedoras, es una mujer muy participativa que irradia buena energía a todo su grupo, vive en el centro de la ciudad de Azogues, tiene 31 años de edad y se encuentra casada y fruto de su unión concibió dos hijos que se encuentran de 11 y 7 años, su esposo trabaja como guardia de seguridad de una empresa, no tienen casa propia y viven en casa de sus padres ya que ellos no se encuentran en el país.

Diana se dedica a la venta de productos naturales  Herbalife hace tres años, también comercializa productos de belleza femenina Avon y Yanbal  hace cinco,  se encuentra en el cuarto ciclo con los préstamos recibidos ha podido adquirir los productos para sus clientes, con el nuevo préstamo que reciba  va a comprar  vitaminas, batidos, suplementos alimenticios, etc. de la línea Herbalife  y  algunas cremas, perfumes, maquillajes de las líneas Avon y Yanbal, su meta es llegar a tener su propio club de nutrición de los productos de Herbalife.
texts.en:
The Más que Vencedoras communal bank is located in the city of Azogues, which is the capital of the Cañar province about 50km from the city where the Ingapirca ruins are located, one of the most visited touristic sites in Ecuador. Azogues and Cañar are famous for their handicrafts, especially handmade Panama hats and ceramic products. The people are friendly and pleasant, like the communal bank members who search for a way to move forward with their families each day.

Diana is a member of the Más que Vencedoras communal bank and she is a very active woman that radiates positive energy to the entire group. She is 31 years old and lives in the center of the city of Azogues. She is married and has two children who are 11 years old and 7 years old. Her husband works as a security guard at a company. They do not have their own house, so they live in their parents’ house now that they are no longer in the country.

Diana has worked selling natural Herbalife products for the past three years. She has also worked selling women’s beauty products from Avon and Yanbal for the past five years. This is her fourth loan and with the loan she has received, she has been able to acquire products for her customers. With the new loan, she will purchase vitamins, shakes, dietary supplements, etc. from the Herbalife line, as well as some creams, perfumes, and makeup from Avon and Yanbal. Her goal is to have her own nutrition club with Herbalife products.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase vitamins, shakes, and dietary supplements from Herbalife, as well as creams, perfumes, makeup and other cosmetics from Avon and Yanbal

loans.name: Jose Balbino

texts.es:
el señor Jose Balbino R. tiene 34 años de edad, esta casado con la señora Denia Elizabeth Colindres quien se dedica al cuidado de sus 6 hijos, tambien le ayuda en el taller de ladrillos.
 
Balbino atiende el taller, se dedica a la elaboracion de tejas, ladrillos, el transporta la materia prima en un carrito que el tiene. 
El producto lo elabora con tierra y barro, tiene dos operarios que le ayudan a fabricar los ladrillos esta actividad la realiza desde hace 7 años. 
 
esta solicitando el credito para la compra de materia prima como ser tierra, leña y barro.
texts.en:
Jose Balbino R., 34, is married to Denia Elizabeth Colindres, who cares for their 6 children; she also helps him in his brick-making workshop. Balbino tends to the workshop where he makes bricks and roofing tiles; he transports his raw materials in a small truck he has. He makes his products with dirt and clay with the help of two employees; he has been in this business for 7 years. The loan will be used to buy raw materials like: dirt, clay and firewood.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood, dirt and clay.

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Our client Dora is part of the Los Diamantes communal bank. This bank, whose name means “The Diamonds” in English, consists of 32 members all hailing from the Cuzco area. Dora is a 44-year-old mother of three and she lives with her children and spouse in the city of Cuzco. 

To make a living, Dora engages in a number of activities. For one, she offers cell phone use for a fee to passersby on the street, somewhat like a modern-day walking payphone. As the Peruvian school year started up in March, Dora also sold school supplies for a few weeks this year. Her real dream, though, is to sell artisan goods. Dora plans to use the loan she receives from Kiva to start up her own business making and selling artisan goods. Specifically, she hopes to buy a machine to help her weave. 

Dora is appreciative and thankful for the loan and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To buy a machine to help her weave

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries, foodstuffs, and sachet water to sell.

loans.name: Raquel Yaquelin

texts.es:
Raquel L. de 26 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Fortín (zona muy humilde con calles de tierra y casa de caña) de Guayaquil. Su casa es de cemento/caña, solo cuenta con luz como servicios básico. Su esposo es pintor, ellos tienen tres hijos de 9, 8, 3 años de edad. 

Raquel decidió hace dos años atrás dedicar mas tiempo a sus hijos por eso ella compro papelerías y artículos para vende. En la parte delantera de su casa ella adecuo un local y lo comenzó a utilizar para su papelería. 

Ahora ella tiene una papelería muy pequeña pero se siente a gusto porque tiene tiempo para sus hijos. Trabaja todos los días desde las 07:00 am hasta las 20:00 pm en las tarde ella les enseña a sus hijos como atender la papelería, Vende papeles, cuadernos, plumas etc. Con el préstamo quiere comprar cemento, bloques y arena para cambiar la parte de caña en cemento.     

En el futuro quiere agrandar y surtir más su papelería, y poder construir mejor su casa para que sus hijas tengas un cuarto cada una.
texts.en:
Raquel L., 26, lives in a periurban area in El Fortín (a very humble area of Guayaquil that has unpaved streets and houses made of sugar cane stalks). Her house is part cement and part sugar cane stalk; the only utility it has is electricity. Her husband is a painter and they have three children who are 9, 8 and 3 years of age. Two years ago Raquel decided to dedicate more time to her children so she bought stationery and other articles to sell. She set up the front part of her house as a store and used it to sell her stationary supplies. Now she has a small stationery shop and she is very happy because she has time for her children. She is open for business every day from 7am until 8pm and in the afternoons she teaches her children how to mind the store; she stocks such items as: paper, notebooks, pens, etc. She will use the requested funds to buy cement, sand and concrete blocks to replace some of the sugar cane stalks with cement. In the future she would like to enlarge and increase the stock of her store as well as to improve the construction of her house so that each daughter will have her own bedroom.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cement, concrete blocks and sand.

loans.name: Moen

texts.en: Mrs. Moen N. is 51 years old, and she lives in Check village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Choeun Kum, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. For supporting this farm, Mrs. Moen N. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. Aside from being a farmer, Mr. Choeun Kum is a cow middleman who can earn a small income to support his family's living. Mrs. Moen N. is a mother of four children who all are attending the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina L. is from the village called Barangay Salvacion, in Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she sells health and medicinal products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $260 a month from these activities.

In 2008, Rosalina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 5th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan J. is from the village of Lower Lodiong, Tambulig. She is 45 years old. Susan is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Susan operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for her business comes from selling daily-use products, such as noodles, biscuits, shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Susan has been engaged in her business for more than seven years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Susan joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC, a Kiva partner. Susan is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Susan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. M. is a middle-aged woman whose husband is shown in the photo. M. has been selling a few fresh fish in the local busy market for more than four years. She sells fish that she gets from her wholesale supplier and from fishermen.

M. is married to Sun Ngoeun, 52, who works as a military policeman in the Ministry of the Interior. The couple has four school-aged kids.

M. is running her fish-selling business smoothly because she has skills in communication which she uses with her customers. However, her income is not very much as her business has come to a low capacity due to insufficient capital. She wishes to have more money to add to her capital which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan of $400.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Lalia

texts.en:
Lalia C. is from the village of Alibago, Enrile, Cagayan. She is 24 years old and married. To make a living, she raises pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $65 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lalia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. 

She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Elida Del Carmen

texts.es:
Elida reside en el municipio de santa Elena departamento de Usulután, está acompañada y vive con su hija de veintiséis años y un nieto de un año de edad, todos trabajan y ella se dedica a la venta de pollos destazados.
El negocio surgió por iniciativa propia no tiene horario de trabajo porque ella tiene su propia granja de pollos los cuales regularmente los vende cada seis semanas ya listos para el consumo, el se ha visto en la necesidad de adquirir el crédito para la compra de mas pollos y concentrado para los mismo, también invertir una cantidad para compra de ropa ya que también se dedica a la venta de ropa.
Esto le permitirá contar con los productos necesarios para satisfacer la demanda de los clientes, obtener más ingresos y mejorar el nivel de vida de la familia.
Las aspiraciones de elida son ampliar el negocio y convertirse en una distribuidora al mayoreo.
texts.en:
Elida resides in the municipality of Santa Elena, in the department of Usulután. She has a partner, and lives with her 26-year old daughter and 1-year old grandson. All the adults in the family work; Elida has a butcher's shop that sells poultry. She began the business on her own and doesn't hold daily hours of operation because she has her own chicken farm. Every 6 weeks she has chickens ready for sale. Elida has realized she needs a loan to buy more chickens and chicken feed. She also has a business selling clothing and will invest in the purchase of more clothes. This loan will provide her with the products necessary to meet her customers' demands, so that she can earn more income and improve her family's living standards. Elida hopes to expand her business to become a wholesale poultry distributor.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase or chickens, chicken feed, and clothing.
